title: The Aftermath of a Food Allergy Anaphylactic Reaction

content: My son had a few reactions when he was a baby, during the time that we were going through the diagnosis process. He had more reactions as an adolescent and teen as he grew into additional food allergies as we navigated additional diagnosis, coupled with accidental exposure. We were very lucky to go for several years between his initial diagnosis as a toddler, and later as a teenager, with no anaphylactic reactions. The most that happened during that long stretch were minor contact reactions by way of hives when traveling or dining out.
The First Anaphylactic Reaction
He has experienced two anaphylactic reactions. One was to peanut that led to an ER visit, and eventual peanut diagnosis, and the other led to another ER visit and confirmation of garlic allergy.

He had several “minor” reactions to peanut from about 8 months old until about 18 months old. We were young parents in early 2000, and there just wasn’t the education and awareness that exist today. We didn’t realize that food allergies are unpredictable. What caused a mild reaction in the past may cause an anaphylactic reaction in the future, and vice versa.

content: When I was introducing him to his first peanut butter and jelly sandwich as a toddler, I had given him peanut previously and never had more than hives. We were never advised to get testing done, avoid the allergen, or otherwise. At the time, we were not completely sure he even had a peanut allergy. Prior to this anaphylactic reaction, he had what many would call a “mild allergy” at best. However, when introduced to the sandwich, he suffered from hives, swelling, closing of airways, pain, and seemed to be losing consciousness.

I grabbed my baby and ran to the car, no shoes, no purse, and raced to the local hospital emergency room. I ran in with him in my arms, past the check-in desk, to the first nurse I saw and frantically exclaimed that I had given him peanut. They quickly assessed my son and whisked him away; IVs and monitors and his sweet tiny little body on a large hospital gurney. They saved his life. I will be forever grateful.

content: This reaction led to diagnosis, which led to education and lifestyle changes to manage his allergies and keep him safe. In many ways, it got easier as the years went on, and this new way of life became second nature.
The Second Anaphylactic Reaction

The second anaphylactic reaction he experienced was years later when we were going through the diagnosis process of new allergies that he was “growing into.” For over 10 years, he was only allergic to peanut and shellfish. He was beginning to react to what seemed like every food. That was because he was now also allergic to garlic, which is in a good number of foods. Since it is not a top 9 allergen, it is often hidden as “natural flavor,” “spices,” and “seasonings.” Pizza, chicken nuggets, soup, potato chips, hot dogs, ketchup, barbecue sauce, sausage, macaroni and cheese, salsa, ranch dressing, teriyaki, and tacos are just a few of the foods that usually contain garlic.
Direct Known Ingestion vs. Cross-Contact and Unknown Sources

content: While his first anaphylactic reaction was from directly and knowingly consuming peanut, resulting in anaphylaxis, the second anaphylactic reaction wasn’t as straightforward. We believe it was due to cross-contact but may never know. That’s the thing about food allergies and anaphylactic reactions – a lot of the stress and anxiety reside in the unknown.

He was at a campout with a church youth group, and while he went with all his own cooking utensils, and we read all the ingredient labels before he left, it seems they also had seasonings that we didn’t check, as well as some shared utensils in the kitchen that were used when separating his food from the rest of the camp food. It started off as a stomachache and quickly escalated to anaphylaxis. One of his church leaders, who also happens to be anaphylactic to bee stings and familiar with epinephrine, administered epinephrine immediately. Symptoms did not subside, and he was given a second dose before being transported to the local hospital emergency room.

This reaction for him in was like a “first,” as he was too young to remember the actual first anaphylactic reaction he had to peanut as a toddler. However, for me as his parent, it was like ripping open what were thought to be healed wounds and reliving past trauma in addition to experiencing the more recent trauma, yet this time, all at once.

sections.heading: Holistic Healing Following an Anaphylactic Reaction
content: I have talked at length with him about how he feels physically, mentally, and emotionally following the most recent anaphylactic reaction, as he was too little to remember the initial reaction. He dealt with it using a lot of humor, and he became even more vigilant of cross-contact and label reading. He continued to politely decline foods at social gatherings, as well as always carry his epinephrine auto-injectors everywhere he goes.
The Fear of the Unknown

He also mentioned with great relief that since he didn’t remember going through an anaphylactic reaction as a child, he was glad that he now is old enough to remember and know what it feels like. Even more so, he is grateful for his quick-acting leaders who administered the epinephrine. He also said that for him, surprisingly, the auto-injectors didn’t hurt, and that helped ease the fear of the auto-injector being administered that he may have previously felt.

sections.heading: The Fallout From Anaphylaxis for a Parent or Caregiver
content: While my son has proved to be very resilient holistically, it took more of a toll on me as his caregiver. It was extremely traumatic for me with his first anaphylactic reaction as a new mother caring for my firstborn child. Then later, many years after that first reaction, for me to let him go on a fun adventure, only to have him have an anaphylactic reaction, hours away from home, was dually traumatic.
I have had to do several things to successfully navigate this journey by his side:
bullets: Focus on my breathing when stress and anxiety creep in.
Consider what I can control, what he can control, and not what we cannot control. Then make a plan and take action. Control is a powerful thing!

Continuously educate my son, his peers, his teachers, our family, and others in our circle about his allergies, cross-contact, label reading, signs, and symptoms of anaphylaxis, and how to administer epinephrine.
Check in with my son and have good communication about his thoughts, feelings, what is important to him, and what his goals in life are.
When he wants to do something, figure out a safe way for him to accomplish his goals so that he can still live a whole full life, even if he may do it a little differently.

content: This journey has not been easy, but we have been refined in so many ways. There are several silver linings to living a life with food allergy and anaphylaxis. While the bad can be tough, there is so much good. One of the ways that I have also worked through the aftermath of socially, mentally, and emotionally working through it as a caregiver is to give back to the community by educating, supporting, and bringing increased awareness to food allergies and anaphylaxis. I’ve always said that if I can help even one other person, it is worth it. And it has been.
Join us on our Food Allergy Support Community page on Facebook.
